title: Seeming and Being Empathetic
summary:
Key ideas:
- Medical schools use scripted responses to teach empathy to students
- Professional medical actors are not always effective in teaching empathy
- Both sides (students and actors) stick to a script, avoiding real human emotion
- Standardized tests are written to be able to hold up in court
- Actual caring is not enough, medical professionals must also appear to care

Key learnings:
- Empathy is a choice and requires exertion
- Consequentialist goals are more important in real life than virtue-ethics-y goals
- Unlearning scripted responses can help medical professionals better connect with patients

Key questions:
- Can medical schools effectively teach empathy without scripted responses?
- How can medical professionals balance appearing empathetic with genuine caring?
- What are some alternative methods for teaching empathy in medical schools?
